name: Monkey 47
why: The herbal sage bridges the 47 distinct botanicals without overpowering the woody, grassy notes.

name: Hendrick's
why: Enhances the signature cucumber infusion and bridges the floral rose notes.

name: The Botanist
why: A clean tonic allows the 22 foraged Islay herbs to shine; thyme highlights the savory undercurrents.

name: Tanqueray No. Ten
why: Unlike standard Tanqueray, No. Ten uses whole fresh fruits. Mediterranean tonic reduces bitterness and emphasizes the citrus.

name: Roku Gin
why: The delicate sakura and tea notes are easily drowned by heavy quinine; a lighter tonic preserves the Japanese craftsmanship.

name: Bombay Sapphire
why: The peppery notes of grains of paradise pair well with the angostura bark in aromatic tonics.

name: Gin Mare
why: Ideally paired with savory herbs to match its basil, thyme, and arbequina olive distillation.

name: Empress 1908
why: The butterfly pea blossom is earthy; elderflower adds sweetness while the acid from grapefruit triggers the color change.

name: Malfy Con Limone
why: A 'lemon on lemon' approach tastes like lemonade; basil adds a sophisticated Italian herbal twist.

name: Drumshanbo Gunpowder
why: The gunpowder tea finish is dry; grapefruit brings out the bitterness while sweetening the citrus mid-palate.

name: Opihr Oriental Spiced
why: A very bold gin; ginger enhances the cubeb and cardamom spice profile better than bitter tonic.

name: Plymouth Gin
why: Plymouth has a distinct earthy rootiness that stands up well to the bitters in aromatic tonic.

name: Sipsmith London Dry
why: The quintessential G&T. A dry, quinine-heavy tonic matches the bold juniper punch.

name: Beefeater 24
why: The Japanese Sencha tea blend pairs beautifully with the lower bitterness of Mediterranean tonic.

name: Aviation
why: Suppresses the juniper to let the sarsaparilla and lavender notes float to the top.

name: Nordés
why: Made with an Albariño wine base; grapes highlight the wine notes rather than clashing citrus.

name: Ki No Bi
why: An incredibly delicate spirit with hinoki wood chips; requires a light touch to not mask the woody flavors.

name: Barr Hill
why: The gin is distilled with raw honey; the acidity of a lemon tonic cuts through the viscosity and sweetness.

name: St. George Terroir
why: Tastes like a pine forest; herbal garnishes reinforce the Douglas Fir distillation.

name: Four Pillars Rare Dry
why: Uses whole oranges in distillation; the tonic complements the Tasmanian pepperberry spice.

name: Ford's Gin
why: Designed specifically for mixing; a classic dual-citrus garnish hits the high and low notes.

name: Citadelle
why: Has 19 botanicals including violet; cinnamon brings out the baking spice undertones.

name: Ungava
why: Uses wild rose hips and cloudberry; grapefruit tartness balances the unique tea-like tannins.

name: Bobby's Schiedam
why: Heavily influenced by clove and lemongrass; the garnish mimics the gin's signature flavor profile.

name: Silent Pool
why: Chamomile and local honey notes are amplified by the floral sweetness of elderflower tonic.

name: Brockmans
why: More like a fruit spirit; berries enhance the blueberry/blackberry infusion.

name: No. 3 London Dry
why: Voted best gin in the world multiple times; grapefruit matches the 3 fruit and 3 spice balance.

name: Martin Miller's
why: Blended with Icelandic water; strawberry brings out the melon-like cucumber notes.

name: Kyrö Napue
why: A Finnish rye gin; cranberries highlight the tart, meadowsweet botanicals.

name: Hernö
why: Winner of many awards; the pepper adds a bite to the incredibly smooth, floral palette.

name: Brooklyn Gin
why: Uses fresh hand-cracked citrus peels; simple lime maintains the fresh, zesty integrity.

name: Cotswolds Dry
why: Non-chill filtered (cloudy); bay leaf pulls out the savory middle notes.

name: Nikka Coffey Gin
why: Distilled in Coffey stills; apple highlights the fruity esters of the unique distillation process.

name: Scapegrace Black
why: Naturally black gin that turns purple; apple provides a crisp contrast to the aronia berry sweetness.

name: Gray Whale
why: Contains sea kelp and almonds; mint freshens the saline, coastal profile.

name: Isle of Harris
why: Infused with sugar kelp; grapefruit acidity cuts through the subtle maritime sweetness.

name: Hayman's Old Tom
why: Old Tom style is sweeter than London Dry; lemon tonic balances the sugar with acid.

name: Bols Genever
why: The precursor to gin (whiskey-like); pairs better with ginger than quinine.

name: Glendalough Rose
why: Distilled with fresh rose petals; elderflower creates a bouquet in a glass.

name: Malfy Gin Rosa
why: Explosion of grapefruit; rosemary adds the necessary savory constraint to prevent it tasting like juice.

name: Tanqueray Rangpur
why: Distilled with Rangpur limes; ginger adds heat to the extreme citrus profile.

name: Whitley Neill Rhubarb
why: Very sweet and nostalgic; ginger ale turns it into a refreshing highball rather than a bitter G&T.

name: Chase GB
why: Made from potatoes (vodka base); ginger creates a 'Moscow Mule' hybrid vibe.

name: Caorunn
why: Uses coul blush apples; an apple garnish is non-negotiable to taste the spirit correctly.

name: Jaisalmer
why: Uses Vetiver and Cubeb pepper; basil highlights the herbaceous Indian roots.

name: Iron Balls
why: Distilled from coconut and pineapple; leans into a tropical profile that fights with bitter quinine.

name: Ferdinand's Saar
why: Infused with Slate Riesling; grapes emphasize the wine character.

name: Bloom
why: Extremely floral and delicate; strawberries add a summer garden finish.

name: Generic: Citrus
why: For citrus-heavy gins, avoid adding more citrus. Use herbs to provide a savory contrast.

name: Generic: Floral
why: Floral gins are delicate. A harsh bitter tonic will crush the petals. Elderflower bridges the gap.

name: Generic: Spiced
why: Spiced gins often lack brightness. The sugars in the orange slice help lift the heavy clove notes.

name: Generic: Dry
why: The classic chemistry: Quinine (bitter) + Juniper (pine) + Lime (sour) = The perfect triangle of flavor.
